Conservative public safety critic Tony Clement is asking for an apology from the CBC after he hung up the phone during a live radio interview about refugees Tuesday morning. 
On morning show “Montreal Daybreak,” Clement said the government needs to add more RCMP resources to stop the growing number of refugees crossing the U.S. border into Canada. 
WATCH BELOW: Tony Clement challenges the government’s integrity of illegal travel to Canada 
The phone call grew increasingly heated as host Mike Finnerty asked Clement for specific details. 
Clement responded that details are up to the government. 
READ MORE: Why are asylum seekers crossing into Canada on foot and what are their rights? 
When Finnerty pressed, Clement hung up, and later took to Twitter to ask Finnerty for an apology. Way to go CBC. Taking a serious issue (illegal crossings) to shout me down on the air. Your tax dollars at work. 
— Tony Clement (@TonyclementCPC) February 21, 2017 
Finnerty responded by saying he’d invite Clement back to the show, but would continue to ask for details on how the RCMP should enforce laws at the border. We'd love to have you back, @TonyclementCPC . We would still need to press you to explain how the RCMP should enforce the law on the border. 
— Mike Finnerty (@finnertymike) February 21, 2017 Getting answers to questions is our job @TonyclementCPC , no apologies for that. Ppl can judge for themselves on tone.There was no shouting 
— Mike Finnerty (@finnertymike) February 21, 2017 Related
